Title: how to prove $437\,$ divides $18!+1$? (NBHM 2012)
Content: I was solving some problems and I came across this problem. I didn't understand how to approach this problem. Can we solve this with out actually calculating $18!\,\,?$
AcceptedAnswer: Note that $437=(19)(23)$. We prove that $19$ and $23$ divide $18!+1$.  That is enough, since $19$ and $23$ are relatively prime. The fact that $19$ divides $18!+1$ is immediate from Wilson's Theorem, which says that if $p$ is prime then $(p-1)!\equiv -1\pmod{p}$. For $23$ we need to calculate a bit. We have $22!\equiv -1\pmod{23}$ by Wilson's Theorem. Now $(18!)(19)(20)(21)(22)=22!$. But $19\equiv -4\pmod{23}$, $20\equiv -3\pmod{23}$, and so on. So $(19)(20)(21)(22)\equiv 24\equiv 1\pmod{23}$. It follows that $18!\equiv 22!\pmod{23}$, and we are finished.
